solution: Since $AB=AC$, then $\triangle ABC$ is isosceles.  Therefore, altitude $AD$ bisects the base $BC$ so that $BD=DC=\frac{14}{2}=7$.  Since $\angle ADB=90^{\circ}$, $\triangle ADB$ is right angled.  By the Pythagorean Theorem, $25^2=AD^2+7^2$ or $AD^2=25^2-7^2$ or  $AD^2=625-49=576$, and so $AD=\sqrt{576}=\boxed{24}$, since $AD>0$.
model_solution:
Apply the Pythagorean Theorem to the right triangle $ADB$ to obtain $AD^2+BD^2=AB^2$, so $AD^2+BD^2=25^2$
Use $BD=\frac{BC}{2}$ to substitute $BD=\frac{14}{2}=7$ into the previous equation to get $AD^2+7^2=25^2$.
$AD^2 = 25^2 - 7^2 = 625-49 = 576$.
$\sqrt{576}=24$
steps: Apply the Pythagorean Theorem to the right triangle $ADB$ to obtain $AD^2+BD^2=AB^2$, so $AD^2+BD^2=25^2$
Use $BD=\frac{BC}{2}$ to substitute $BD=\frac{14}{2}=7$ into the previous equation to get $AD^2+7^2=25^2$.
full_steps: Apply the Pythagorean Theorem to the right triangle $ADB$ to obtain $AD^2+BD^2=AB^2$, so $AD^2+BD^2=25^2$
Use $BD=\frac{BC}{2}$ to substitute $BD=\frac{14}{2}=7$ into the previous equation to get $AD^2+7^2=25^2$.
